ansible/roles/keystone/defaults/main.yml.message:
Thinking about this again, I think we might need an 'enable notifications' flag at least for keystone since its a bit different from the rest. That was probably the intention of enable_cadf_notifications, even if it didn't get it quite right.

How about adding 'enable_keystone_notifications' in here, possibly also 'keystone_notifications_topic'.

We could even set it to enable_cadf_notifications by default, and provide a clean transition with a deprecation.

Sorry to change again on this, it's a bit fiddly.

WDYT?

ok. I see what you mean. It is all due to the third-party integrations that Keystone might have.

Can you see my last changeset? I am not using 'enable_cadf_notifications' there though.

How about:

{{ enable_cadf_notifications | bool or enable_ceilometer | bool }}

Given that this did actually work (see other comment), I'm concerned about backwards compat.

Does ceilometer actually consume keystone notifications though?

Much of kolla-ansible is undocumented (and possibly even misleading). That doesn't mean we can throw backwards compatibility out of the window.

As I mentioned elsewhere, the default value for the topics option is 'notifications', which means it doesn't need to be set to make it work. That is why I changed my mind about this.

To be fair, it's not even that misleading. If it is 'no', CADF notifications are disabled. If it is 'yes', CADF notifications are enabled. The only minor issue is it sets a config option to a value which is already the default.
Mark, the point is it is misleading (CADF already default), half-broken (topics not set anyway) and *undocumented*. I don't think it deserves more than a mention in the upgrade notes.
Sorry if I wasn't clear enough.
For most services, notifications are only enabled if ceilometer is enabled. Enabling notifications without something draining the rabbitmq queues will cause problems.

True that. That is why there is the check there. However, as you pointed out, we might have third party integrations. That is why I externalized this to `keystone_default_notifications_topic_enabled`. Also, because of that, I addressed the issue with versioned notifications in Nova here as well.

I agree keystone_default_notifications_topic_enabled is the right path forward, I'm just saying we can't break backwards compatibility without a deprecation period. It's really not a big deal to keep enable_cadf_notifications around for a release or two, and use it to set the default for keystone_default_notifications_topic_enabled.
now, I see what you want here. I will reintroduce the parameter then.

My problem with "enable_cadf_notifications" is that it is misleading. That is what I discussed with Rados during the first version of this proposal, which was way smaller.  We (my team here) just discovered this, because when debugging an issue between barbican and Ceilometer, we noticed that Keystone was not generating notifications. We were using `enable_cadf_notifications=no` because we did not want the CADF format, but we wanted notifications. We interpreted the name of that property as an indicator of the format only, and not something to enable/disable notifications. Moreover, we checked that the default is already CADF in Keystone. Therefore, what we needed is something to enable/disable notifications in Keystone, which is what is being proposed here.

With the introduction of `keystone_default_notifications_topic_enabled` (as you suggested), we now get a method to enable/disable notifications in Keystone as well (without needing to rely on Ceilometer).

> Does ceilometer actually consume keystone notifications though?

Yes, it does.
Ah, clear now. All those funny defaults made me confused. Agree with Mark here.

I agree it is misleading. We can deprecate enable_cadf_notifications, but I was only happy to remove it when I thought it was useless. Now that I know it is not (because it does actually enable keystone notifications), we need a deprecation period while we transition to a new variable.

Here is the problem. The issue (our issue here) is not with the default for the topic name ('notifications'). The issue is that the default for the driver is '' (empty). Therefore, it does not send notifications, when CADF is set to 'no'. However, (at least) from our perspective, the opposite of CADF (CADF='yes') is not 'noop' for the driver of oslo messaging, it (when CADF='no') is 'basic' format for notifications.

In a minimum viable deployment with Kolla-ansible we would expect notifications to be activated for the most common systems such as Nova, Keystone, Glance, and so on. That is why I went through the systems that declared the oslo messaging section (I assumed they were the most important ones because people somehow already declared the oslo messaging sections there) and applied the approach that is used in Nova. The format, for instance, can be then configured using the overriding mechanism.

ansible/roles/keystone/templates/keyston.message: Agree this is useless, given the keystone default.
This would be better represented by a 'keystone_notification_format' variable, but we normally don't provide variables that map to a single config option.
I mean - remove and not add a new one. ;-)

Do we also need to configure notification topics? For example, nova has this:

nova_notification_topics:
  - name: notifications
    enabled: "{{ enable_ceilometer | bool or enable_searchlight | bool or enable_neutron_infoblox_ipam_agent | bool }}"
  - name: notifications_designate
    enabled: "{{ enable_designate | bool }}"
  - name: vitrage_notifications
    enabled: "{{ enable_vitrage | bool }}"

nova_enabled_notification_topics: "{{ nova_notification_topics | selectattr('enabled', 'equalto', true) | list }}"

It also only sets the driver if one or more topics are configured. This pattern seems to be fairly consistent throughout kolla-ansible.

That would make sense to me, but I haven't spent a huge amount of time with keystone notifications. Are they normally published to ceilometer?

If we remove enable_cadf_notifications then we would be removing the ability to control whether keystone notifications are enabled.
Would you guys like to see something like this in Kolla-ansible with respect to Keystone configurations?

Yeah, I had that thought too but forgot. The thing with keystone is probably that it's external systems that would like to listen for its notifications anyway.
The default topic is 'notifications' which probably is wrong in many cases unless we like all notifications in one bag.

Slight backwards compat issue: if a user had set enable_cadf_notifications to true and manually overridden the topics, their notifications would stop if neither ceilometer nor barbican are enabled. It's a bit of a corner case.
I would say so. I will create a release notes with an upgrade note
Solvable by upgrade note I guess?

neutron/agent/common/ovsdb_monitor.py.message: By the way, I'm also thinking about having a separate list for modified ports.

There is one (big) inconvenience if the ofport changes: the OVS firewall. Being considered as a new ("added") port will trigger the "self.sg_agent.setup_port_filters" method, adding this new port to the firewall.

But the "old" one (actually the same but with an nonexistent ofport) is still present in the firewall.

Considering this new port as "updated" won't update the firewall rules, so you need to find a way to:
- Inform the OVS agent about this change.
- Change correctly this information in the firewall.

Indeed, that's the main issue that we were trying to fix. After applying this patch, the old ofport rules were cleaned up by this: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/8e73de8bc42067c0a6796df3cca9938d25ae754e/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/ovs_neutron_agent.py#L1486-L1504

why don't You add those ports to "updated_ports"? IMO it seems more logical choice rather than "added" but maybe there is some other reason, like updated_ports are treated in slightly different way?

This optimization was introduced by this patch: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/commit/75edc1ff28a460342a9b5e5b7d63c6f4fb59862d.

releasenotes/notes/bug-1845986-95cbede0a.message:
right so to clarify, in its current state on master,
SEV will only cause the error below if you enable have the following image metadata properties are set

- (hw_disk_bus=scsi or hw_cdrom_bus=scsi) and hw_scsi_modle=virtio-scsi
- hw_video_model=virtio (this is the default on arm but SEV only works on AMD x86_64
- hw_qemu_guest_agent=yes

in all other cases it should work correctly.

the error is caused because when any of the above combination of image properties are set a virio devices
is created without instruct qemu to use dma mappable memory for the device by setting driver=iommu.

as a result SEV will try to encrypt the device memory which will cause the guest kernel to lockup when udev tries to initialise the devices.

sev will be functional if the default disk/video models are used and if the qemu disk agent is not used.

note those are the 3 ways we know would break.

i am unclear if using the serial proxy or spice console woudl also be non fucntional.

for reviews this is the proposed fix
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/684825/

in its current from it woulfix the virtio-scsi case and the video model.

the qemu guest agent is not adressed by that patch

nit: this is proably clear enough but just to be pendainic

the point we are trying to make is if sev is enabled then setting any of the combination below will  cause the error.

so you are implictly oring the bullet list and if any of the set is true then the bug will present.

that is how i read it but other might read it differently.

as i said on irc the only thing i would change is make it clear that its

``hw_scsi_model=virtio-scsi`` and (``hw_disk_bus=scsi`` or ``hw_cdrom_bus=scsi``)

that can obviouly be translated in English rather than python.
yep that look fine to me.

In base line 956, failover audit wait for the state out of SM_FAILOVER_INTERFACE_RECOVERING before proceeding the rest of the steps.
The original design for waiting for the recovery is to avoid unnecessary failover if the recovery comes in quick enough. With the new failover fail_pending state, it is already provided a small (2sec) wait period for i/f state change, before react to a failure.

nova/service.py.message: If the change focuses on the Status of nova service-list (enabled/disabled), suggest to use "status" instead of "state", because in nova service-list, state is to indicate the binary service is up or down
I think it would be better to have this class extending 'service.Service' then Service to extend ServiceWithAdminStatus

Sahid, thanks for your comments. 

In theory, your suggestion would be preferred and should be done from the beginning when Service is introduced. 

In practical, since a lot of service are using Service, it would have wide impacts if Service is extended from this class. The current approach is to limit the impact and try to get the correction in for Console Service only. The next step would be directly modify the Service class, make the fix available to all services using Service class and have more testing to other services using Service class.
It's not clear for me when this get updated ?

service_ref.disabled refers to the "disabled" field of objects.Service. It would be updated when "nova service-disable" command is executed. 

service_ref.disabled is updated by nova.servicegroup.drivers.db._report_state method. This method is executed periodically (as configured by report_interval) and calls objects.Service.save to save the changes. The objects.Service.save method will read back the latest data from database after saving the updates (the updated "disabled" field would then be available to the service_ref object). 

This is existing behavior and this commit doesn't change it.

I think we need to discuss howto handle config files/dirs. At SUSE we want to support multiple config file locations and also config snippets. So it would be something like:

/usr/bin/ceilometer-api --config-file /usr/share/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf --config-file /etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf --config-dir /etc/ceilometer/conf.d/common/ --config-dir /etc/ceilometer/conf.d/ceilometer-api/

Where:
- /usr/share/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf : the unmodified config provided by upstream
- /etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf : empty file
- /etc/ceilometer/conf.d/common : A directory where config management systems (Chef, Puppet, ...) can drop their files in. Also users can drop files into it. The common/ dir is read by all services

This is actually correct, BIOS is an acronym so it should be all caps, but in most of this document you have it in lowercase. Either way, I'd suggest picking one and being consistent throughout.
Done

I'm not very familiar with Redfish. Are these key/value pairs part of a standard or are they vendor specific?

I see specific vendor and model referenced in the example below so I'm wondering if that's required as input to Redfish or if it's metadata for human convenience or if the BIOS settings as described in HardwareProfile.yaml are going to consist of vendor specific key/value pairs.
BIOS settings in hardware profile will be generic, driver-impl will internally handle for the specific vendor param (HP/Dell)

The BIOS settings key/value pairs are not standardized and they differ from vendor to vendor. For example Dell uses key SriovGlobalEnable to enable SRIOV but HP uses key SRIOV. So HardwareProfile.yaml for Dell and HP have to specify settings corresponding to that vendor.
The request/response models for Redfish API are expected to be standardized. But due to evolution of Redfish API there are some discrepancies like having Attributes field in response of bios settings. Currently I am looking at Dell iDRAC 8 and HP iLO 4/5 to identify discrepancies and need to get hold of iDRAC 9.

I dont see a need to generalize BIOS settings in hardware profile and change them to vendor specific. Instead the hardware profile for Dell/HP should specify the bios settings based on the vendor. This way drydock via redfish driver pushes the configuration to Redfish server on node.
nit: needs -> need
Done
There are no security impacts associated with modifying BIOS settings?
The communication between drydock driver and the baremetal node (Redfish server) is via HTTPS with session authentication.

during the document validation or at deployment runtime? If we can know this at the time of "commit configdocs", it would be a lot more obvious to the user that something configured is being ignored due to the current OOB driver.  If we only warn at runtime, the info would likely not be seen by the end user.
Agreed, updated with your suggestions. This can be done by adding new validator in drydock.

I would rather use a multi-line string, containing a text ()json, xml) document with full BIOS configuration from hardware vendor. Yes, it will be vendor-dependent, and even more - hardware model dependent.
It would be a pain to support key/value pairs for multiple vendors, and it would be easy to set-up one BIOS of one server model, dump config, remove specific server details, and then apply this config onto every server of the same model.
Then we would think of how to apply BIOS settings which are server-specific (e.g. node name) to each of the servers.

Well, it would be pain to maintain in deckhand.
Whereas with multi-line string you could just copy-paste what vendor provides.
As per the discussion in Weekly meeting, will leave it as key/value pair.

I would prefer key/value pair to keep the HardwareProfile document clean and able to modify parameters in a cleaner way programmatically. We can have separate hardware profile documents for different vendors and use deckhand substitutions for the common bios parameters if required.

Are these API calls authenticated? Does Drydock automatically know where to obtain the appropriate credentials for each OOB IP or does there need to be something in the YAML that tells Drydock where to retrieve the credentials from?

Yes the API calls are authenticated. Credentials can be provided in Site manifests of Drydock (to be specific, HostProfile) documents. Ex: https://github.com/openstack/airship-treasuremap/blob/3a1038e122349aa6599691a7e2c6bf167e93d744/global/profiles/host/cp.yaml
is there an intent to parallelize this across all the nodes being deployed, or are we stuck with sequential?
Current implementation already supports execution of subtasks of driver actions in parallel upto maximum of 16 workers. So maximum of 16 nodes will be configured in parallel.
Write what happens if ConfigBIOS returns an error? Do we retry? Do we retry only under certain conditions.
Updated the spec. No retry will be done in case of failures. Subtask status will be updated with failure message and no further actions will be taken on that node.

deploy-guide/source/app-policy-overrides.message:
This appendix explains the purpose of policy overrides and shows how to enable them.

.. important::

    Overrides are available on a per-charm basis and will be
    noted in a charm's README. Always consult the charm
    documentation prior to enabling this feature.

Applying overrides
++++++++++++++++++

Policy overrides for an OpenStack service are applied by attaching the compressed file to the corresponding charm and then enabling them by passing an option to the charm. These are both done via Juju commands.
The compressed file, say ``overrides.zip``, is attached to the charm in this way:
I don't think any of this is needed.
I think it's clear that the overrides apply to the charm. We can drop these words.

Override status

n.b. Throughout our docs I'd like to move away from the expression "workload status".

Suggested text for this section:

===

The status of the overrides for a Juju application is shown in the output for the ``juju status`` command. When overrides are successful the text ``PO:`` (for Policy Overrides) will be prefixed to the application's status message. When they are unsuccessful ``PO: (broken)`` will be used.

<< It would be grand if we could get command output here >> 

Unsuccessful overrides imply that **none** of the default policies have been modified. In this case, the operator should either fix and re-attach them to the charm or disable the overrides entirely (i.e. set ``use-policyd-overrides`` to 'false').

Information on broken overrides will appear in the logs.

doc/source/1910.rst.message: I got thrown by the sentence "The policy defaults...". Does this refer to the defaults provided by the charm or the new override feature? If the latter, I'm not sure if this is the place for it. If the former, I feel more detailed information is in order.
It is unclear how this feature can be used by the operator.

Now that I see https://review.opendev.org/#/c/682033 , I think we should keep things short in these RNs. Consider:

===

The Policy Overrides feature provides operators with a mechanism to override policy defaults on a per-service basis. Specifically, it allows for the modification of policies that determine the permissions of the tenants and users of the system.

Policy defaults for an OpenStack service are defined via "policy-in-code" and/or via a default policy YAML file provided by the charm. The operator can use the new feature by providing a ZIP file consisting of at least one YAML file which contains policy rules that the service will observe when responding to API queries.

This feature is being provided in the following charms:

- designate
- glance
- keystone
- neutron-api
- neutron-gateway
- nova-cloud-controller
- nova-compute

For further details consult `Appendix N: Policy Overrides <https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/charm-deployment-guide/latest/app-policy-overrides.html>`_ of the Charm Deployment Guide. The README for each of the above charms also mentions the new feature.

===

Random musing but I was thinking about how if we had something tracking instances to build held outside the lock and then removed them when we gained the lock (not really this level, more like within rt.instance_claim), when shutting down the service we could at least log the instance uuids that are pending a build to help later debugging. Or even writing out a file to the host on shutdown if there are pending builds so we could easily read that file on restart and put those instances into ERROR state if they don't have a host set (then we wouldn't need to get allocations and all that from placement). Anyway, those are kind of pie in the sky ideas and I'm not sure they are very good, just something I was thinking about while thinking about this change. If the RT tracked what was in the queue for the big lock and the compute manager could do something with that on shutdown/restart it could be useful, but it's a fuzzy idea at the moment.

Hmm, are you sure? What if I've got a server with no ports attached, will I still get the default security group back when showing server details? Looks like maybe not:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/867401e575d2b27b9bc63ceda41cd85233545cd5/nova/api/openstack/compute/views/servers.py#L627

Definitely more context needed here, I agree. I thought it was a bug that security_groups wasn't included in the response. I'm pretty sure I left comments somewhere on this review to that effect. Will I fix that bug?

So this statement in the commit message is wrong, but I'm not sure it's worth respinning this for just this change.

The other things in here about updating the api-guide, I opened a bug for that and is already wrong before this, it's just we didn't realize until your change here so don't worry about updating that in this change.

Same with the api-ref saying that security_groups are required in the GET response, that's latent and can be fixed separately.

The only other thing in here is that the NeutronFixture is unconditionally returning security groups and I think it should only do that if the server has an info cache with VIFs in it which won't be the case if the server was created with networks='none'. Dealing with that could be done in a respin or a follow up. If you respin, then update the commit message to fix the false statement.

https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1846656

nova/tests/fixtures.py.message: Based on the comment in the commit message, this would likely be more accurate if we filtered out servers that have an empty network info cache meaning they have no ports attached. Note that we have lots of functional tests that don't care about networking really so they create a server with networks='none'.

As noted above, there are several functional tests which explicitly create a server without networks just because they don't care about networking for the test (speed things up, not deal with the networking fixtures, etc).
+1. I thik till now we do have network in all POST server request but yes we should take care of this case here.

nova/tests/functional/test_servers.py.message:
Hmm, I think this is an unintended side effect but the set of keys you get in a down cell case is actually pretty specific, or supposed to be, it's in the API guide:

https://docs.openstack.org/api-guide/compute/down_cells.html

So I guess maybe that's a bug in the docs if you can get that today and it's just our fixtures that weren't working properly? Although gmann was asking about this earlier in the week...yeah must be a bug in the down cell docs.

For GET /servers/detail we start here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/867401e575d2b27b9bc63ceda41cd85233545cd5/nova/api/openstack/compute/views/servers.py#L396

call show() for each server:

return back to detail from here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/867401e575d2b27b9bc63ceda41cd85233545cd5/nova/api/openstack/compute/views/servers.py#L210

and then go on to add the security groups:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/867401e575d2b27b9bc63ceda41cd85233545cd5/nova/api/openstack/compute/views/servers.py#L410

And because we call neutron to get ports by server id:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/867401e575d2b27b9bc63ceda41cd85233545cd5/nova/network/security_group/neutron_driver.py#L317

rather than use the network info cache (which doesn't contain information about security groups) I guess we do proxy to neutron in the down cell case.

I'll let Surya know...or open a docs bug, something like that.
